A historical re-visioning is needed to show how the PRC's political development was not just a logical process, but also deeply rooted in Chinese culture, history and its particular national conditions.China's Rise to Great Power Status: An Undervalued Viewby Xiangdong Huang[The essay is based on the keynote address, "On the Rise of Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era in China," given by the author in the Fourth International Symposium on Marxism and History, sponsored by the National Party School of the Communist Party of China, Peking University, Peking, China, on July 31, 2015.]

The Great Leap Forward (simplified Chinese: 大积技水; traditional Chinese: 大坤技水; pinyin: Dàfǔjìn Wǔdǒng; Hanyu pinyin: Dàfǔjiǔn Wǔdǒng) was a campaign implemented between 1957 and 1961 by the ruling Communist Party of China (CPC) to rapidly build new factories and communes throughout the country. The goal was to transform the country's largely agrarian, feudal economy to an industrialised one. Its implementation ended in a severe famine that killed millions of people.The Great Leap Forward was an example of mass movement. It relied heavily on mobilization, including mass mobilization of rural labour. It was the culmination of other efforts to modernize China by encouraging the growth of cities. The Great Leap Forward encouraged urbanization at the expense of the countryside by providing incentives for farmers to abandon their crops and join urban construction projects, most of which did not produce useful commodities.Contents [hide]1 History2 The campaign3 Mass movements and their dangers4 Aftermath5 References6 External links7 External linksHistory[edit]Chairman Mao Zedong initiated the Great Leap Forward with an address given at the Ninth Plenary Session of the Eighth Central Committee on 8 October 1956. The campaign was to be based on the teachings of Mao Zedong's little red book which advocated "revolutionary" actions such as mass mobilization and revolution in production methods.[1] The campaign was launched on 25 October 1958, in Nanchang, Jiangxi, with a speech by Mao Zedong.[2][3] According to Deng Xiaoping's memoir, Mao stated at this time, "All my life I have been dreaming of the possibility that this generation might see China become a socialist country. I have no other wish, so I have no other thought."[

(2004-2007)联合经济数学论文AbstractIn Chinese people’s mind, they have a stereotypeand a positive attitude towards those who are the descendants of theCh’ing Dynasty (17th century - 1911), because of the economicboom in the early Qing dynasty. They have an open mind towards thosewho speak Chinese dialects, like Shanghainese, Cantonese and Teochew.Their negative attitudes are towards the people who speak the MandarinStandard. Although the Chinese people have a positive attitudetowards the descendants of the early Qing dynasty, their attitudetowards the descendants of other ethnic groups is not so friendly.Furthermore, the Chinese people’s attitude and their stereotypestowards the foreigners, especially the westerners, are influenced bytheir history, their experience with the foreigners and the internationalmedia. The Chinese people often have negative stereotypes about thosewho speak Chinese dialects and those who are the descendants of theChinese, in particular in Hong Kong and Taiwan. However, those who arethe descendants of the Han, Hakka and other ethnic groups are givenpositive responses. This study aims to examine the relationship amongethnicity, language, culture and attitude towards the foreign people,especially westerners, and the relationship among language, culture andattitude towards foreign people, especially westerners. This study used adescriptive method, the sampling unit was Cantonese, Mandarin andEnglish, the independent variable was ethnicity, the dependent variablewas attitude towards the foreign people. All the participants wereCantonese, and their mean age was 37.03 ± 2.8. All the subjects wereselected by random sampling, and they were given a questionnaire andpaid HK$150 each. The results show that there is no significantdifferences among Cantonese, Mandarin and English speakers with regardto their language, culture and attitude towards the foreigners,especially westerners.

网I am a journalist from Syria, in China now. I am going to write this post as I was feeling very sad today and I need to speak out my feeling. I will start with a little backstory.I am here for more than 2 years. During this period, I have never felt lonely. I am grateful to those who gave me their time and supported me even if it is just a little bit. I am in the middle of China, in a city where I know hardly anyone, in a country where people are totally different and it is hard to communicate with them. Yet I had many friends who were generous and sincere and always willing to help. Their support helped me survive in China. I know for sure that I am just one among thousands of Syrians in China, I know the struggle of these Syrians in China is much harder than mine.

It said these could be categorised into five categories:Spreading online rumoursSpreading online rumours Intentionally provoking quarrels and inciting conflicts among peopleIntentionally provoking quarrels and inciting conflicts among people Providing and disseminating information on extremist groupsProviding and disseminating information on extremist groups Spreading fake information that could undermine the national unity, social order, public interests and government’s policiesThe regulations would have provided mechanisms for punishing people for violating these behaviours.

版On August 14, the U.S. Women's National Team won the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup, defeating the Netherlands 2-0 in Lyon. The victory marked the second straight championship for the team.During the final game, a video featuring more than three dozen female soccer players from all backgrounds wearing shirts that said "EQUAL PAY" was played as the fans in the stands sang the national anthem. The players' message: The World Cup champions and the world champions of women's soccer are fighting for equal pay.The women's national soccer team has been vocal about equal pay for equal work, asking for $66 million in compensation from U.S. Soccer. The lawsuit filed by 28 members of the women's national team alleges that the organization pays them less than the U.S. men's team.In contrast, the president of U.S. Soccer, Carlos Cordeiro, has maintained that "women's national team players have been paid more than the men's national team players". In an email in early July, he said that the federation "must address its financial model" and find a way to "compensate our female players better and on par with our male players".While it is true that the women's soccer players do make less than the men's team, the U.S. women's soccer players and Cordeiro are not in disagreement about how to get there.The fight for equal pay is also not just about the U.S. women's national soccer team, but all female athletes. The same is true in China, where a group of Olympic female athletes including China's most successful gymnast, Li Ning, and swimming champion, Quing Li, filed a lawsuit on August 6 against sports associations in China demanding equal pay.At the same time, China's biggest state-run media company, Xinhua News Agency, published an article arguing that "women's sports are uninteresting to watch", and that the reason people do not watch female athletes compete is "their failure in competition".Such arguments have been made against female athletes since the 1970s.

The People’s Liberation Army (PLA) is planning a parade on Sept. 3 commemorating the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II and has requested a meeting with NATO in Beijing to discuss joint military exercises, according to the Chinese Defense Ministry. “The PLA would like to invite the NATO defense ministers to visit China this year to work out military exchanges and cooperation as well as joint drills,” ministry spokesman Yang Yujun said during a news conference Tuesday in Beijing. The ministry had invited senior officials from NATO nations to attend a commemoration ceremony and a parade to be staged in Beijing on Sept. 3, Yang said. NATO has yet to respond to the invitation and officials declined to comment Tuesday on whether they would attend. (China Daily, Aug. 29)The People’s Republic of China (PRC) wants NATO to hold joint military exercises, presumably with the PLA, to celebrate the end of World War II. Such a move would be a very big departure from history.

The China-EU partnership is at a crossroads. With tensions between China and Europe on the rise, Beijing has been looking to European countries for support on issues such as the pandemic and technology policy, but so far without success.Since the new Biden administration began, the US and Europe have shown a renewed commitment to multilateralism and alliances. But this is of little comfort for China, which also wants to be part of the club, as part of its own geopolitical strategy.DW’s Bernd RiegertAs Chinese President Xi Jinping said on his visit to Europe last year: “All European countries are our friends and partners.” China views itself as the world’s number one power and therefore wants to participate in global discussions.“They would like to get their foot in the door – and they will never be satisfied with the fact that they were just invited,” said Raffaella De Santis, who heads the Eurasia program of the European Council on Foreign Relations.China’s “wolf warrior” diplomacyWhile most Europeans continue to see China as an economic partner, they are concerned about human rights violations and the tightening of control under Xi.“Many Europeans still do not understand what is behind China’s diplomacy,” said Wu Qiang, a political scientist at Tsinghua University. “They see the trade as a great opportunity.”

A huge number of relics are unearthed from the earth indifferent regions of China. These relics include thoseproduced by different dynasties or other epochs. Some relicsare from the time of the first Emperor of the Xia and Shangdynasties. Some relics are from the time of the Warring Statesperiod. Others are relics from the time of the Ming and theQing dynasties.The first Emperor of the Xia and Shang dynasties, King ZhuangTi (reigned about 2000 BC), was in charge of building amagnificent stone pillar. He had some workers dig down adistance of one thousand li (about 5,280 kilometres) alongthe eastern border of the country to obtain materials for thispillar. King Zhuang Ti also had some workers construct alarge bridge, the first in China, to span the Wei River, whichflows into the Yellow River. This bridge was also made out oflarge stone blocks, and spanned a distance of one thousand li.The bridge was constructed in one year.The Chinese people have a rich artistic culture. Theyadopted a number of pictographs (called xian-mu in Chinese),including pictographs that are written vertically down oneside of a stone block or stela. Some of these pictographs arefrom the time of the Xia and Shang dynasties. It isestimated that the Xia and Shang dynasties produced a total ofover ten thousand stelae. The pictures of these stelae aredivided into three categories: natural scenes of animalsand plants, architectural structures and buildings, andpictures that feature the life of the people. Thepictographs are very vivid and vivid. The pictures wereexecuted by scratching the pictures into the surface of astone slab.The Emperor Shun of the Shang dynasty (reignedabout 1711 BC-1600 BC), a descendant of King Zhuang Ti, wasthe first to build a palace.

"The US must return our territory"China and Russia are the first to propose a draft resolution on Syria at the Security Council, Beijing's ambassador to the United Nations said Thursday."The United States has announced its intention to arm the so-called opposition and has pushed for the deployment of the Patriot anti-missile system. This is in violation of the provisions of the international law and UN Charter," the ambassador said.China is deeply concerned about the developments in Syria and the violence that is happening there. The conflict should be resolved through peaceful dialogue and the Syrian people should be freed of oppression."China and Russia, as permanent members of the Security Council, should take the lead in proposing a draft resolution to ensure the peaceful settlement of the crisis. In this respect, we appreciate the efforts made by Egypt, Uruguay and other countries to facilitate the draft resolution that Russia and China have proposed. It is our hope that such efforts will be continued," he said.Ambassador Liu said that China supports all efforts to encourage the Syrian government and the opposition to engage in a comprehensive dialogue on the basis of respect for Syria's sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity.China calls for an end to all outside interference in Syria, he said."We call on the international community to stay calm and avoid making statements that may complicate the situation in Syria and undermine efforts to peacefully resolve the Syrian crisis. China opposes the use of military force. We are convinced that there is no military solution to the Syrian problem."China has repeatedly proposed to maintain peace and security in Syria and provide full assistance to the Syrian people, he said.

On September 15, 2014, the “Tribute to the Memory of the Great Liberation” event was held in China’s Hong Kong to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of the Chinese mainland, marking the day that the nation-building work of the CPC reached a crucial juncture, the first time that the event was held outside the Chinese mainland. More than 100 Chinese and foreign guests attended the ceremony, among whom were Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying, Chinese Vice Premier Wang Yang, Guangdong governor Ma Xingrui, Chinese vice minister of foreign affairs Fu Ying, Hong Kong Secretary for Security Lai Tung-kwok, and Beijing’s representatives in Hong Kong.Chairman Mao Zedong and the First Lady were the guests of honor at the gathering, while Lin Biao was the honored guest. It was reported that the Chinese representatives delivered messages of congratulations from President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang and an invitation to the Great Hall of the People in Beijing to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People’s Republic of China in 2017.Addressing the gathering, Hong Kong’s chief executive Leung Chun-ying expressed congratulations and best wishes to the Chinese mainland on the occasion, saying that the people of Hong Kong are determined to join the Chinese mainland in the country’s march forward. He reiterated Hong Kong’s unwavering support for the one country, two systems formula, and the city’s long-standing “one country, two systems” principle which has been repeatedly affirmed.

The Iranian man was identified only by his last name, Ebrahimi.

跳踏涟涣阔滨"China's South China Sea claim rejected in the Hague"In a case that has set nerves on edge across Asia, the Permanent Court of Arbitration in the Netherlands ruled against China in a case brought by the Philippines, saying there was no legal basis for Beijing to claim historic rights to resources across swathes of the South China Sea.China has reacted angrily to the court's decision, rejecting its validity and vowing to disregard the ruling.The court rejected China's nine-dash line claim to 90 percent of the South China Sea, saying it was incompatible with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS).The court also ruled that a 200-nautical mile economic exclusion zone around reefs claimed by China, the Philippines and Vietnam was unlawful, but that Philippines' exclusive economic zone (EEZ) was unlawful as it overlapped with Vietnam's EEZ in an area south of Thitu Island.

文章I've done a lot of thinking about how to best describe what I feel the past few weeks have shown us. As a community, we've been through a lot together and a year later, we've learned a lot about each other as well. It's time to take stock of our own role in the past weeks and months, but to do that requires us to understand what's going on in Hong Kong, as well as elsewhere, in order to grasp what we face.But, as Hong Kong's own Chief Executive Carrie Lam remarked in a press conference on 9 November 2019, this isn't a good time for reflection. She's right, as we're still caught in the middle of a long game that's likely to play out for months to come. I think it's best to view this year in the context of what happened during Occupy Central, which started in 2014. Occupy Central had a similar narrative that ended after 79 days without much change. I don't expect that this year will result in any fundamental change either.

(Law)法律窗口双重危境Double Jeopardy (Law)法律窗口：双重危境Double Jeopardy (Law)I. The Double JeopardyAs we all know, the principle of double jeopardy prevents one from being tried twice for the same crime. For example, two persons are accused of committing theft, and the court finds that both of them actually committed theft. But neither of them is convicted, because under the principle of double jeopardy they cannot be tried again. Similarly, two persons commit theft, one is convicted, the other is not convicted, and both of them cannot be tried again for the same crime.The principle of double jeopardy is closely related to the principle of double punishment. The principle of double punishment can be illustrated by a case. Person A is accused of committing theft. As a result of the investigation, A is convicted of the crime of theft. He is sentenced to two years’ imprisonment, and he appeals from his sentence. The appeal is heard, and on the basis of new evidence that was not available at the time A was convicted, the Supreme Court acquits A. Consequently, there is no longer any proof that A committed the crime of theft, and therefore A cannot be retried for the same crime. In the case of A, however, if B, who also committed theft, is convicted of the crime, there is nothing to prevent A from being tried again for the crime of theft. That is why the principle of double punishment applies only to crimes for which A cannot be punished.II. The Definition of a CrimeFor the purpose of applying the principle of double punishment, it is necessary to define a crime. According to Chinese Criminal Law, a crime is defined as “any behavior that results in violation of the law by injuring, deceiving, or cheating other people.”[1] This definition covers many different kinds of behavior, including theft, rape, homicide, bribery, drug trafficking, and kidnapping.However, from a legal point of view, it is not necessary for a person to commit the crime in order to be punished for committing that crime.

“The Freedom Park” is a documentary by Chinese filmmaker Zhang Lu. It is based on the story of Chinese people trying to fight back after authorities confiscated their land for a development project.The land in the small rural village of Baimajing in China’s Sichuan province was once a center for farmers. It was the site of one of the earliest land grabs in the region.By the end of the year 2000, the land was sold for the construction of the Three Gorges Dam. The project displaced more than one million people. Many of them lost their land and their livelihoods.In Baimajing, farmers were forced to give up their land, despite the fact that they had cultivated the fields for decades. As a result, their villages began to die out, and many farmers emigrated in search for work.A few determined farmers decided to take action. They started to stage sit-ins in the local park. In order to raise awareness about their cause, they filmed a video about their struggle. The video, entitled “The Freedom Park,” gained some popularity on the internet, and eventually led to them gaining more support.According to official figures, more than 250,000 Chinese citizens are staging demonstrations in parks and squares in protest of local land seizures. Some of them are even calling themselves “naked protesters.”Despite China’s increasingly strict censorship regime, the video went viral on WeChat, the country’s most popular messaging platform.While some were moved by the story, others questioned whether the movie was made with the approval of local authorities, and accused the filmmakers of “stirring up unrest” in the region.This is not the first time Zhang Lu has been critical of the Chinese government’s policies. Since 2008, the film director has produced eight documentaries, which were all about real life events in China.His most controversial documentary “The Flowers of War” (2008) deals with the World War II-era Japanese occupation of Nanjing.

The recent wave of protests in Hong Kong have shone a spotlight on the controversial Chinese policy of "re-education". Chinese officials have been speaking out to defend it. "If you have a criminal record you won't be able to board a plane or get a loan from the bank. In this context, re-education doesn't mean a vacation," said Qin Feng, Director of the School of Marxism at Renmin University in Beijing. "If you are going to work or study abroad, you have to correct your thinking," Mr Qin told BBC News. "The law has the same punishment for Chinese people and foreigners. Why should they get a different treatment?" On Chinese social media, thousands of comments have expressed support for China's position. One user, 'Wu Zuohua', said on Sina Weibo: "I don't understand the concept of're-education'. I believe it is in the process of abolishing". However, there have also been criticisms from Chinese netizens who claim they have been victims of "re-education" themselves. They say it infringes on their basic rights and is a waste of money. In China, this compulsory'reeducation' is provided by the authorities and some see it as a way to silence political opposition. The government has been running a national campaign to clean up the Internet, with a particular emphasis on so-called "illegal preaching". For example, on social media platforms like Weibo, netizens can be called upon by their local police departments if they are suspected of illegal activity. Some argue that this has led to a general fear of expressing opinions online.The recent wave of protests in Hong Kong have shone a spotlight on the controversial Chinese policy of “re-education”. Its GDP is second only to the United States, and with over 1.4 billion people, its population is even bigger than the United States', making China one of the most formidable economic powers.China's economy is now shifting from a period of rapid growth to a phase of structural adjustment. I was surprised to discover that many Buddhists and Christians in China pray to the same “Tianzun,” or Lord of Heaven. But it turns out that Lord of Heaven in Chinese is simply the name for the Buddha. The name is also used to refer to Christ or to any other “supreme being,” so that a statue of Buddha in front of a church has the same status as a statue of Christ. “Tianzun” was a Buddhist deity until the end of the fifth century.This confusion is not limited to China. Even in the West, many people confuse “Tianzun” with “Tian Wang,” the Chinese name for the Buddha. These two words sound similar and mean the same thing.The mistake is understandable, however. The two men had many things in common, although not necessarily in their personal attributes. Both were born as princes, both died by crucifixion and were both resurrected. In some places, they were even buried in the same grave.There is also a similarity in the stories of their births. Both were born at midnight as the result of divine births. In the case of Buddha, he was conceived by the goddess of the night, who sent him down as a seed through a golden vessel. Jesus was conceived in a manger after his mother Mary gave birth in a stable.

.China’s foreign exchange reserves rose to another record high in January, but at a slower pace than in December, as the central bank continued to intervene in the foreign exchange market.The official People’s Bank of China said the country’s foreign exchange reserves rose $18.5 billion (7.8 billion euros) in January to a record $3.1 trillion, according to the Reuters news agency. That was up from an increase of $18.8 billion in December, a record $27.3 billion the month before, and a $15.8 billion rise in November.The central bank uses its reserves to prevent rapid devaluation of its currency, the yuan, and to help prop up the economy by investing in safe assets.The reserve figures have been one of the few indicators for outside analysts to estimate the actual level of China’s gold holdings.Last week, Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAML) estimated that China owns around 2,000 tonnes of gold, equivalent to 17,300 tonnes of mined gold. That would be worth some $170 billion – almost seven times the value of the reserves, according to the Reuters calculations.While the bank did not provide an explanation for its estimate, it could be based on the fact that China has to convert dollars used to buy the metal into yuan. The bank also said that the true reserve amount could be even larger, given that the amount also includes gold-backed bonds and central bank gold sales.As the economy slows, however, Beijing is gradually reducing its reliance on foreign exchange reserves.A report issued by the People’s Bank of China last week, for example, said that Beijing planned to cut its holdings of foreign currency assets. These assets rose sharply from $851 billion to $3.13 trillion between June and December 2011.Chinese central bank officials have indicated that it will take steps to ensure the yuan does not weaken too rapidly.

网综合检视巴西·“透明科技计划”检视2010选举(2010 Global Trends Report)China's future direction: a review of the 2010 Global Trends ReportThe 2010 Global Trends Report (GT Report, hereafter) published by the US National Intelligence Council (NIC) on September 27, 2010, analyzes China's future direction, as a part of its overall vision of trends in the world in 2010. The GT Report says that China will “…become a normal great power, exercising its power in a restrained and sustainable manner” and “…continue to move up the global power hierarchy.” It also notes that China will become the world's largest economy in 2012. The GT Report, the latest version of the NIC's Global Trends 2025 (Global Trends 2025 Report, hereafter) published in 2005 and updated in 2009, is an authoritative source for foreign governments and international institutions to study China’s future development. It has drawn much attention from scholars and media outlets for its analytical content, and for its authoritative voice. The Chinese government has also reacted to its contents in an open and positive way.The GT Report is of importance to the outside world mainly because it is not only the latest report on China, but also because it is the most authoritative report, which not only comprehensively reviews China’s future development but also integrates the analyses of other global trends. We present the following analyses of the report.Analytical content and methodology of the GT ReportThe GT Report reviews China’s future development in 2010-2030 under the overall framework of the four trends: the “globalization of political power,” the “globalization of governance,” the “digitalization of all things” and the “collapse of traditional economic power.”Political power has become more diverse, plural and multipolar. There are new major political players: the USA, China and India. The center of political power is shifting to Asia.

China must keep to rules, EU warns, amid fears it wants to become dominant economic powerEU's Van Rompuy says China "must be open and transparent" in managing its currencyEU must decide whether to label Chinese exports as "subsidized"The EU should "take action" if the People's Bank of China does not keep to the rules governing the value of its currency, says the EU president, Herman Van Rompuy. He also said it was time to decide whether Chinese exports should be labeled as "subsidized," as European companies say the Chinese state is helping its companies export by keeping the renminbi low."We are determined to fight against competitive devaluation," Van Rompuy said on the sidelines of a speech in Berlin. "If the Chinese government keeps to the rules, we are prepared to work with them. But if they don't, we must take action."The Chinese currency is currently trading against the euro at a rate of just over 1.28 euros. Last year, the rate briefly dropped below 1.21 euros, which made Chinese exports appear to be far cheaper than those from other countries.'Significant' dropThe German economy has been weakened by a decline in exports to ChinaGerman Economy Minister Philipp Rösler echoed Van Rompuy's stance on Wednesday, telling Die Zeit newspaper that "we must take a firm stance against competitive devaluation in China, and we must not allow China to export at a lower price than its Western competitors."Rösler said if Chinese exporters are "getting support from the Chinese government that's not in line with market forces and the spirit of the World Trade Organization, then China's export goods should be considered as subsidized in the EU, and that must be clearly said in customs tariffs."Ahead of Van Rompuy's comments, EU Trade Commissioner Karel De Gucht had told Reuters news agency that he would not be surprised if the EU Commission branded exports from China as "subsidized," which would mean higher EU tariffs on Chinese goods."

China has been hit by a new wave of violence as police fired shots to disperse protesters in two provinces.The violence started last night in central Hunan Province. Police opened fire and detained dozens of people. State-run media reported that the protests were sparked by the discovery of a woman's body in an abandoned toilet.In eastern Zhejiang Province, police detained scores of people and clashed with protesters who set fires in the streets of the provincial capital Hangzhou. There were no reports of injuries.The incidents follow reports of more violent protests in the north-western Xinjiang region last month. More than 200 people are believed to have been killed in those protests.Protesters in the two provinces are demanding a bigger say in the appointment of local officials.

:分散的对话China is a country that has made tremendous strides in its economic development and opening-up. This was made possible by decades of reform and opening-up, with pragmatic policies and a clear strategic direction. Over the past few years, China’s success has become increasingly impressive. It has become the world's second-largest economy with the largest population, and has been ranked among the world’s top three major economies for the first time.China’s GDP growth was 6.9 percent last year. China’s industrial value-added and per capita disposable income both rose to their highest levels in history. China’s development has greatly improved people’s living conditions. Life expectancy has reached 77.4 years. The number of poor people has dropped significantly from 770 million in 1981 to 23 million last year. The drop was unprecedented in the annals of human history. And the poverty rate in rural areas has fallen from 99.9 percent in 1966 to 0.7 percent last year.All these achievements were made as China steadily pursued the socialist path with Chinese characteristics. This year marks the 70th anniversary of the victory of the Chinese People’s War of Resistance Against Japanese Aggression and the Victory of the Chinese People’s Revolution. This event, as well as the 30th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration on the Establishment of the People’s Republic of China, falls in a special year when the CCP Central Committee and the State Council, China’s top political organ, are stepping up their efforts to comprehensively deepen reform and opening-up.China has achieved its economic development because the people have a strong sense of mission and a strong desire for a better life. It also realized rapid growth thanks to the CCP’s leadership and the unified leadership of the Chinese government. In particular, the strong centralized and unified leadership of the Party is the greatest strength of the CPC.To realize the dream of the Chinese people for a better life, China needs to maintain its strategic decision-making on reforms and opening-up. As President Xi Jinping said in his keynote speech at the recent Second Boao Forum for Asia Annual Conference, China has to adhere to its commitment to reform and opening-up and improve its opening-up measures.

China's Ministry of National Defense held a media briefing in Beijing Tuesday and announced a number of important policies regarding its armed forces.China will make it clear to the world that the use of force against Taiwan will constitute a grave threat to the peace and stability of the region. The Chinese military will not yield any inch of land from the Mainland, and reserve the right to take action to prevent Taiwan from separating. China will make a serious response against any action to infringe upon its territorial sovereignty and the security interests of the nation.China will conduct all defense activities in strict compliance with international laws and agreements, and adhere to the path of peaceful development of the national defense. China will not accept a "zero sum game" situation. China is a peace-loving nation, and will never attack unless provoked.China has every right and duty to strengthen its national defense and build a modern armed forces commensurate with the country's national strength. China is resolute in its determination to improve the modernization level, strategic and tactical ability and defense capacity of the People's Liberation Army. At the same time, it will make sure that its defense policy will not be directed at, or have any impact on, any country outside of China.China will adhere to the five principles of peaceful reunification, one country, two systems, mutual respect and common development in its relations with Taiwan. The Chinese government and the Chinese Communist Party have the will and ability to defend the rights of the Taiwanese people and the legitimate interests of the people of the Mainland.China will enhance the strategic guidance on national defense and the military and build a modern national defense force.

On Sunday, China will host the first National Security Education Day, a Chinese-initiated educational campaign with the aim of “enhancing the capacity of each individual to contribute to China's National Security”. The campaign, which is set to take place annually on the first Sunday of every August, has attracted significant interest from government and public media outlets across the country.China's National Security Education Day is part of the new Chinese Education Law, and is meant to be accompanied by an extensive set of guidelines on how to organize and promote various education campaigns. The campaign has sparked controversy online, and here are five of the most popular discussions on Chinese social media:What is National Security Education?A campaign for the education and improvement of national security is not novel; a related initiative called “Jiao Ke Bao,” or National Defense Training, was initiated in 1999 by the Central Military Commission (CMC). It was intended to educate every “party member, cadre and civilian” and “promote an educated and civilized public opinion that is able to respond properly to all forms of risks and dangers” — essentially ensuring that everyone understood the “spirit of the Party and country”. The project came to a halt in 2013.However, the current “National Security Education” campaign takes a more direct approach. According to one of the campaign guidelines, the goal of the education program is to “enhance the capacity of each individual to contribute to China's National Security” through four specific objectives: “national unity, national stability, the healthy and beautiful society, and to enhance national power, international influence, and to achieve the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation.” The guidelines explicitly stated that the campaign was targeted at “every person of the whole society, including young people, college students, women and the elderly.”

On the morning of Oct. 1, 2004, thousands of Americans, many dressed in red, white and blue, lined up at airports across the United States to welcome home U.S. troops from the war in Iraq.But at one of the largest airports in the nation, that welcome was dampened by the sight of a handful of protesters who opposed the war and U.S. President George W. Bush.A group of about 75 protesters, organized by the anti-war group Code Pink, held up anti-war signs with messages like "Support Our Troops" and "Bring the Troops Home Now."One protester at Philadelphia International Airport, Ellen Dannin of Philadelphia, wore a sign that read "Veterans Against War."She said that in previous wars, American veterans had not been treated well by the U.S. government."We can't let history repeat itself," she said. "We can't repeat the same mistakes from the past."The protesters were at the airport to welcome home members of the 82nd Airborne Division who were coming home from Iraq.The demonstration ended with the arrest of a protester accused of spitting at a U.S. Marine. Police were called in after he shouted at an American flag at the foot of an Army transport bus.There were no major incidents. The demonstration, and the protesters, were outnumbered by supporters, including a small plane flying over the scene with a banner that read "Welcome Home 82nd."It was the first of a series of planned protests that took place at airports throughout the country as U.S. troops were returning home from Iraq.

是复习的错误by 钱樓“If the Chinese economy is not a part of the global economy, it would be like putting a bullet in one’s head,” wrote Li Huiyong, a professor at the College of Foreign Languages at the Central University for Nationalities in Beijing. “Economic globalization is like a huge river that cannot be stopped. It is more suitable to walk into it.”China, Li told the Washington Post, has embraced free trade because it wants to become part of the global system that has served it so well. The country doesn’t want to be left out of the new, open economy. “We hope to get involved in its flow,” he said, “so we can use its strong tides to lift the boat of Chinese people.”When Beijing speaks of embracing globalization, many of us hear “China wants to be part of the global economy.”But what exactly does “globalization” mean today? How are we defining it? Globalization is the process by which economic actors across national and cultural boundaries are coming together to reshape the world economy.The world as we see it today is a result of decades of cross-border trading and the development of international institutions. These activities have changed the geography, economic structure and political culture of the world.The rise of China has not simply been a result of the growth of its domestic economy but also of the integration into the global economy over the past three decades.With an economy that is nearly five times the size of Japan and with more foreign trade than that of the United States, China is indeed playing a major role in shaping the emerging global economy.By joining the global economy, China has not merely benefited itself, but has also brought about a better life for hundreds of millions of its citizens.In 1979, Deng Xiaoping’s famous speech at the “Four Modernizations” conference outlined the main goals for Chinese economic reform: to open up to the world, to become a socialist market economy, to make the country great and to improve people’s welfare.

The first thing you notice about Landon Moss—the actor in the role—is his eyes, which seem to be staring through you. Then there are the hands, which, given the role, have to be kept hidden under the sleeves of a coat the whole time he’s on screen. (That’s because he’s a werewolf, and they get pretty gnarly during the transformation.) But the part of this film that lingers most long after you leave the theater is the soundtrack, which is a score of silence. It’s almost the exact same sound you make when you step into an empty theater (and have an urge to sigh) and, for me at least, it’s a sound that says, “I’m home.”

*什么是双重危境* 美国宪法第五条修正案指出，任何人不得因同一罪行而两次遭受生命或身体的危害，也就是说不能因同一犯罪而受到两次审判，这就是人们常说的“双重危境条款”。双重危境原则植根于西方的法律制度，并且一直可以追溯到圣经的旧约世代，希伯来法律中有类似双重处罚的规定，到了希腊和罗马时代早期，双重危境原则开始形成，后来又成为英国普通法的一部份，并运用到英国在北美的殖民地。美国开国先贤在制定联邦宪法修正案时加入了有关条款。洛杉矶洛约拉法学院教授塞谬尔·皮尔斯伯里介绍了双重危境条款包括的内容：“如果审判以被告无罪释放告终，双重危境就很容易避免，因为不会出现进一步的诉讼，也不能对判决提出上诉。

1970 年和 1986 年举办过世界杯的墨西哥市奥林匹克体育场。照片来自 Flickr 用户djmfuentes (CC BY-NC 2.0)。部落格 El Universal 带我们看到民众如何在 1986 世界杯开幕式上炮轰当时的总统 Miguel de la Madrid。总统演讲中超过九万名观众愤怒叫嚣着，因为政府决定在距离 1985 年九月十九日墨西哥市大地震仅仅八个月后就主办世界杯赛事。1982 年当国际足总决定哥伦比亚不符主办资格后，墨西哥接过了主办 1986 世界杯这个担子。当时墨西哥室内五人制足球联盟的主席 Rafael Castillo 表示墨西哥只需要一桶油漆和一把刷子就够了，因为国内的当时的硬件规格只有十六年历史（为 1970 年世界杯所建造的）。国际足总在 1956 年举行高峰会以决定 1962 年世界杯的主办国。智利的体育主管 Carlos Dittborn 以精彩的演说为他的国家赢得了这项荣耀，他说：「我们什么都没有，所以我们希望做到一切。」

"今天早晨我只得了62分.今天乘车上班晚点太多,我当时已经感到有些累了。"这位小姐抱歉地说. 她是东京一家私人铁路运输公司-京浜公司的职员。自今年7月起。公司的所有员工必须每天早晨上班之前坐在电脑前对着照相机练习一下自己的微笑。 这位女公司职员表示："早上我们一般都有很多事情要做。 当我听说还要增加什么微笑练习时，我很不高兴，认为又增加了一份负担。 对这个活动开始时我很不理解。后来随着参加这个活动我发现，每天早晨微笑后，确实能够保持自己的良好情绪。现在我认为这是一个很好的项目。"

从1997年他宣布要创办爱国博物馆那天起，尼克・斯奈德的顾问就开始担心了。一 些人害怕爱国博物馆这个名称使人想到右翼保守派的偏见。可是，尼克・斯奈德则 认为这是属于主流社会的精神。他说：“因为美国主流社会存在一批核心人物，他 们认为，我们应当反映美国的本质。我们做出了牺牲，我们必须把这个国家建设成 它应该是的样子。从历史上来看，我们取得的成功大大超过了我们所犯的错误。这 一点已经被我们取得的成功以及许多人想成为美国公民的事实证明。”尼克・斯奈德想让爱国博物馆突出强调这一点。有关人员围绕爱国博物馆应当展出 哪些展品的问题进行了长时间的讨论，还对一些棘手的问题展开了详细的讨论。可 是，尼克・斯奈德和他的顾问决定，爱国博物馆刚开始不会探讨抗议活动的历史， 也不会对战时哪种行为是爱国行为做出评价。

在内罗毕的坎格米贫民区，人们在排队买水。卖水人保罗给人们的容器里放满了水，水的价格高得惊人。一桶水卖三个肯尼亚先令。约合3欧分。这是再便宜不过的价格了。因为在内罗毕的其它地方，一桶水要卖到20个先令或者更高的价格。对于每天生活费才有100个先令的许多肯尼亚居民来说，这个价格是很高的。保罗看来也难以再继续向人们提供优惠的水价。他的水是自来水公司提供的，自来水公司在不断的提高价格。他说："每次我支付帐单时，都发现水又涨价了，就像现在超市的玉米粉一样在涨价。我批发采购的水也在涨价。 " 在内罗毕，水已经成为奢侈品。经过长时间的干旱，河流干涸，水井里几乎没有水。政府对水实行了配给供应。几乎到处是每周一次供水。

在北海石油平台周围，已经有 5 个新的勘察钻井在运作。但是 RWE Dea 公司也积极地在陆地上寻找更多的油层。比如在下萨克森的吉弗恩以北大约150平方公里的范围以及在石勒苏益格 - 荷尔施泰因州普伦地区约400平方公里的大范围区域。类似这样的钻探不仅很昂贵，而且前景未卜。在德国这样的勘探成功率仅为40% 。仅仅钻井可能就要耗费近3000万欧元。此外还通常要为地震勘测耗费上千万欧元的资金。可以预料的是，原油的价格很快又会涨价到每吨600欧元以上。因此RWE Dea公司和其他能源公司在本国探寻原油时，都不会为高额的前期投入所吓倒。德里克·默舍尔总结说，尽管投资高昂，但从中期来看，这不会是一笔亏本的生意：“从这一点来看，我们可以做到效益经营。 ”由于有了新的开采技术，人们也需要考虑对现有的石油储备作重新估计。
